Updated AGENTS.md with mandatory task board protocol. Updated TOOLS.md with dashboard Docker internal URL (solobot-dashboard:80) and quick commands.

archive.title: SoLoBot-Android: Remove password prompt on gateway connect
archive.description: Removed password dialog from Android app. promptForPassword() now calls connectDirect() which skips password and connects immediately using Ed25519 device token auth. Deleted PasswordDialog composable. Files changed: MainActivity.kt, MainViewModel.kt.

archive.title: SoLoBot-Android: Add model selection in settings
archive.description: Added model selection dropdown in Android Settings screen. Uses sessions.patch RPC to set model per-session (matches dashboard behavior). Models grouped by provider with context window and reasoning info displayed. Files: MainViewModel.kt, SettingsScreen.kt.

archive.title: SoLoBot-Android: Color code agents in header (match dashboard)
archive.description: Applied per-agent color coding to FilterChip components in ChatScreen.kt using getAgentColor() helper. Colors match dashboard exactly: main=#BC2026, dev=#6366F1, exec=#F59E0B, coo=#10B981, cfo=#EAB308, cmp=#EC4899, family=#14B8A6, tax=#78716C, sec=#3B82F6.

archive.title: SoLoBot-Android: Add dashboard theme system
archive.description: Added System/Dark/Light theme selector in Settings. Theme preference persisted via DeviceAuthStore DataStore. Applied Material3 dynamic theming. Files changed: MainActivity.kt, MainViewModel.kt, SettingsScreen.kt, DeviceAuthStore.kt.

archive.title: SoLoBot-Android: Full audit & improvements
archive.description: Removed debug println and visible debug text from TTS UI. Fixed branding moltbot→SoLoBot throughout. Fixed cleanMessageContent() regex that was incorrectly stripping curly braces from message content. Added TTS/reply tag cleanup. Fixed duplicate HorizontalDivider in chat.

archive.title: Fix task board data persistence — prevent wipes on sync/redeploy
archive.description: Implemented 3-layer data protection: (1) Server /api/sync now compares item counts and never overwrites with fewer items for tasks, activity, or notes. (2) Client syncToServer() fetches server state first, skips pushing if local has fewer items. (3) Client loadState() keeps whichever source (server vs localStorage) has more data and pushes preserved data back. Files: server.js, dashboard.js. Pushed to GitHub, container restarted.

archive.title: Android: clickable links + reply notifications
archive.description: Implemented clickable links in chat messages via ChatMarkdown.kt using ClickableText + URL detection and link styling. Added ChatNotificationHelper with reply notification channel + preview. Added NodeRuntime observer to trigger notifications when app backgrounded, with dedupe signature and foreground check. Changes committed in SoLoBot-Server (commit 1ff64a38c).

archive.title: Cross-session notifications (Dashboard + Android)
archive.description: Add notification support for messages from agents when user is not in that session. Dashboard: browser Web Notifications API + visual badge on session tabs. Android: local notifications when messages arrive for non-foreground sessions. Both use WebSocket connection to gateway.

archive.title: Fix browser caching — no more hard refresh needed
archive.description: Added Cache-Control headers to server.js static file serving. HTML/JS/CSS files now use no-cache + ETag (MD5 hash) so browser always revalidates — gets 304 if unchanged, fresh file if changed. Images cached 1 hour. /api/state uses no-store. SPA fallback also gets no-cache + ETag. Deployed via Coolify auto-deploy. Files changed: server.js.

archive.title: Fix notification click → navigate to chat + correct agent
archive.description: Fixed browser notification onclick handler to also call showPage('chat') and setActiveSidebarAgent() so clicking a notification navigates to the chat page and highlights the correct agent in the sidebar, not just switching the session key. File changed: dashboard.js.

archive.title: Kanban board: sorting, filtering, and workflow features
archive.description:
Added comprehensive kanban board features:

TOOLBAR (new, above columns):
- 🔍 Search: live-filters across titles + descriptions as you type
- Sort dropdown: Newest first, Oldest first, Priority high→low, Priority low→high, A→Z, Z→A
- Priority filter: All / P0 (🔴) / P1 (🟡) / P2 (🟢)
- Agent filter: auto-populated dropdown from all tasks, shows agent-colored options
- Bulk actions: appears when tasks selected — bulk Done, Archive, Delete with confirmation
- Task stats: 'X tasks ��� Y% done' running summary

TASK CARDS (enhanced):
- Agent color tag chip on each card (matches sidebar agent colors)
- Description preview: first 80 chars shown inline under title
- Relative age: 'today', '1d ago', '5d ago' etc.
- Quick ▶ Start button on To-Do cards (moves to In Progress)
- Column header counts show filtered/total when filters active (e.g. '3/7')

AGENT DETECTION:
- Primary: task.agent field (CLI script now sets this automatically as 'dev')
- Fallback: title prefix + keyword heuristic (android→dev, marketing→cmp, etc.)
- Colors: main=#BC2026 dev=#6366F1 exec=#F59E0B coo=#10B981 cfo=#EAB308 cmp=#EC4899 etc.

FILES: index.html (toolbar HTML), dashboard.js (+231 lines sorting/filtering/rendering logic), dashboard-tasks.py (agent field)
Pushed to GitHub, Coolify auto-deploying.

archive.title: Redesign kanban toolbar — compact single-row layout
archive.description: Redesigned kanban toolbar from 4 stacked full-width rows (~120px tall) to a single compact horizontal row (~26px tall). Search field capped at 160px, dropdowns use short labels (Newest, P*, Agent), bulk actions are tiny icon buttons only shown when needed, stats pushed to far right. All controls visible at a glance without dominating the board. File: index.html. Pushed to GitHub, Coolify auto-deploying.

archive.title: Fix cross-session notifications + sidebar unread badges

External now returns Cache-Control: no-store and index.html references dashboard.js?v=3.53.1. Stale HTML caching resolved; SMM sidebar + notifications should persist.

archive.title: Adjust toast colors + duration to match theme
archive.description: Updated notification toast styling to follow theme CSS vars (card-bg/text-primary/text-secondary), use agent color as accent only. Increased auto-dismiss to 12s. Added softer shadow + backdrop blur.

archive.title: Fix session model persistence when switching sessions
archive.description: Implemented per-session model persistence: added applySessionModelOverride() to sync model/provider from sessions list, called on connect and after switchToSession. Uses availableSessions model and refreshes sessions if needed.

archive.title: Ensure provider sticks with session model
archive.description: Ensured provider dropdown syncs to session model on changeSessionModel (add missing provider option + set value). Deployed.

archive.title: ✅ Test task - SoLoBot can now track tasks
Investigate SMM session losing conversation history
archive.description: Investigated SMM session losing history. Root cause: gateway context compaction. SMM session was running heavy browser automation (tool calls eating tokens), causing the gateway to compact older messages. Not a dashboard bug. Explained to SoLo.

archive.title: Increase compaction threshold for SMM agent
archive.description: Set SMM agent compaction override in openclaw.json: maxHistoryShare=0.8 (up from default 0.5), reserveTokensFloor=4096, memoryFlush enabled. This keeps 80% of context window for history instead of 50%, giving SMM significantly more room before compaction kicks in.

archive.title: Sync Android notification clears with dashboard read state
archive.description: Implemented read-ack sync: Dashboard sends chat.inject [[read_ack]] when unread cleared; gateway-client ignores read-ack for notifications; dashboard ignores read-ack in chat display. Android clears unread/notification on read-ack in both active and cross-session handlers.

archive.title: Update OpenClaw to latest upstream
archive.description: Ran gateway update.run. Update skipped because install is not a git checkout (not-git-install). Gateway restart signal emitted. Current version remains 2026.2.3.

archive.title: Fix session model/provider persistence on session switch
archive.description: Fixed model/provider not persisting on session switch. Root cause: applySessionModelOverride did nothing when session had no model set, leaving stale UI from previous session. Fix: 3-tier fallback ��� (1) cached availableSessions, (2) fresh sessions.list from gateway, (3) global default from openclaw.json via config.get. Commit 9fb0b4e.

archive.title: Fix dashboard text selection/copy-paste issues
archive.description: Task cards onclick handler fires when trying to select text, opening detail modal and killing selection. Also Ctrl+A hijacked for task selection instead of text. Need to check for text selection before firing click handlers.

archive.title: Secure noVNC setup for SMM agent
archive.description: Set up secure noVNC access on VPS for SMM agent desktop access. VNC on :5905, websockify on localhost:6080, nginx reverse proxy with SSL + basic auth on port 6090. Firewall: blocked direct 5905/6080, allowed 6090. Systemd services enabled for persistence. Credentials: smm / 5L5eqFguTG82/9fSUOV7tw==

archive.title: Debug VPS connectivity from container
archive.description: Root cause: UFW had no rules for ports 80/443 — only 8080 was allowed. Added 'ufw allow 80/tcp' and 'ufw allow 443/tcp'. sbdash.sololink.cloud now returns 200 from container. SSH was unaffected (port 22 was already allowed). Internal Docker network was also unaffected.

archive.title: Dashboard: SMM agent sidebar visibility
archive.description: SMM sidebar confirmed live on external URL (sbdash.sololink.cloud). No-cache headers pushed (c7784a0). UFW port 80/443 restored. SoLo notified via sessions_send.

archive.title: Audit dashboard chat system — reliability, sync, missing messages
archive.description: Audit found 6 bugs: (1) textContent undefined in loadHistoryMessages causing misclassification, (2) localStorage only saved 50 msgs, (3) 24h cutoff silently dropped old msgs on reload, (4) gateway only fetched 50 msgs, (5) maxMessages cap at 100, (6) mergeHistoryMessages didn't persist chat. All fixed in commit 40480b6.

archive.title: Fix chat switching bugs - wrong conversation on refresh + slow agent switching
archive.description: Root cause: chat messages stored in single global localStorage key (solobot-chat-messages) regardless of which agent session was active. Fixed by: (1) session-scoped localStorage keys (solobot-chat-{sessionKey}), (2) in-memory message cache for instant agent switching, (3) legacy key auto-migration. Pushed to solobot-dashboard main. Awaiting Coolify redeploy.

archive.title: Fix Android TTS noise/artifacts in voice playback
archive.description: Created TtsSanitizer utility that strips markdown, fenced code blocks, inline code, [[tts:]] and [[reply_to:]] tags, antml tool call XML blocks, HTML tags, bare URLs, emoji shortcodes, and noise lines (NO_REPLY, HEARTBEAT_OK, [read-sync], [[read_ack]]). Wired into TalkModeManager.playAssistant() so text is cleaned before hitting ElevenLabs or system TTS. Also added type-check filter in fetchLatestAssistantText to skip tool_use/tool_result content blocks. Added unit tests. Pushed to main.

archive.title: SoLoBot Android Session Audit
archive.description: Completed full session audit and implemented critical fixes: (1) Added sessionVersion counter to prevent stale history responses after session switches, (2) Switched all history loads from merge to full replace to eliminate cross-session message bleed, (3) Added limit=200 pagination to chat.history, (4) Fixed false message dedup using content hash, (5) Tightened addMessage dedup to ID-only, (6) Unified session key source of truth, (7) Removed premature history fetch after sendMessage, (8) Added removedSessions pruning. Files changed: MainViewModel.kt, GatewayRepository.kt. Pushed to main.

archive.title: Settings: provider+model selector, move theme to Visible Panels

SMM sidebar entry missing intermittently. Need to add cache-control headers to proxy config or force Caddy to pass through without caching.

Auto-selects current model's provider. Sync already works bidirectionally via sessions.patch — Android changes update dashboard, dashboard changes picked up on 5-second refresh. Pushed to main (2846e24).

archive.title: Dashboard: Remove chat widget from dashboard page
archive.description: Removed embedded Chat bento widget from pages/dashboard.html (dashboard page). Chat remains available via the dedicated Chat page. Pushed to main (812f40e).

archive.title: Dashboard: Fix recent-activity 404
archive.description: Server now special-cases /api/memory/recent-activity.json: serves from workspace/memory/recent-activity.json if present, otherwise returns empty payload to prevent console spam. Pushed (218a7cf).

archive.title: Fix Skills Manager toggle API (unknown method skills.toggle)
archive.description: Root cause: dashboard Skills Manager called non-existent gateway RPC , causing toast 'unknown method: skills.toggle'. Gateway supports  with params { skillKey, enabled }. Patched /home/node/.openclaw/workspace/solobot-dashboard/js/skills-mgr.js to call  and treat displayed name as skillKey. Committed+Pushed: 2281299.

archive.title: Fix skills.install failure visibility + npm install errors
archive.description: Diagnosed npm install failures: gateway runs as user 'node' inside moltbot container; /home/node/.npm cache had root-owned files causing EACCES. Also global npm prefix was /usr/local which wasn't writable for node. Fix applied on VPS: docker exec into moltbot container, chown -R node:node /home/node/.npm and /usr/local/bin + /usr/local/lib/node_modules; set npm prefix back to /usr/local for node user. Verified npm install -g @steipete/bird and mcporter succeed as node user.

archive.title: Verify bird skill end-to-end
archive.description:
Verified bird skill is installed and runnable on gateway host (inside moltbot container): /usr/local/bin/bird exists and bird 0.8.0 — fast X CLI for tweeting, replying, and reading
Usage: bird [options] [command]

Post tweets and replies via Twitter/X GraphQL API

Options:
  -V, --version                             output the version number
  --auth-token <token>                      Twitter auth_token cookie
  --ct0 <token>                             Twitter ct0 cookie
  --chrome-profile <name>                   Chrome profile name for cookie extraction
  --chrome-profile-dir <path>               Chrome/Chromium profile directory or cookie DB path for cookie extraction
  --firefox-profile <name>                  Firefox profile name for cookie extraction
  --cookie-timeout <ms>                     Cookie extraction timeout in milliseconds (keychain/OS helpers)
  --cookie-source <source>                  Cookie source for browser cookie extraction (repeatable)
  --media <path>                            Attach media file (repeatable, up to 4 images or 1 video)
  --alt <text>                              Alt text for the corresponding --media (repeatable)
  --timeout <ms>                            Request timeout in milliseconds
  --quote-depth <depth>                     Max quoted tweet depth (default: 1; 0 disables)
  --plain                                   Plain output (stable, no emoji, no color)
  --no-emoji                                Disable emoji output
  --no-color                                Disable ANSI colors (or set NO_COLOR)
  -h, --help                                display help for command

Commands:
  help [command]                            Show help for a command
  query-ids [options]                       Show or refresh cached Twitter GraphQL query IDs
  tweet <text>                              Post a new tweet
  reply <tweet-id-or-url> <text>            Reply to an existing tweet
  read [options] <tweet-id-or-url>          Read/fetch a tweet by ID or URL
  replies [options] <tweet-id-or-url>       List replies to a tweet (by ID or URL)
  thread [options] <tweet-id-or-url>        Show the full conversation thread containing the tweet
  search [options] <query>                  Search for tweets
  mentions [options]                        Find tweets mentioning a user (defaults to current user)
  bookmarks [options]                       Get your bookmarked tweets
  unbookmark <tweet-id-or-url...>           Remove bookmarked tweets
  follow <username-or-id>                   Follow a user
  unfollow <username-or-id>                 Unfollow a user
  lists [options]                           Get your Twitter lists
  list-timeline [options] <list-id-or-url>  Get tweets from a list timeline
  home [options]                            Get your home timeline ("For You" feed)
  following [options]                       Get users that you (or another user) follow
  followers [options]                       Get users that follow you (or another user)
  likes [options]                           Get your liked tweets
  whoami                                    Show which Twitter account the current credentials belong to
  about [options] <username>                Get account origin and location information for a user
  user-tweets [options] <handle>            Get tweets from a user's profile timeline
  news|trending [options]                   Fetch AI-curated news and trending topics from Explore tabs
  check                                     Check credential availability

Examples
  bird whoami
    Show the logged-in account via GraphQL cookies

  bird --firefox-profile default-release whoami
    Use Firefox profile cookies

  bird tweet "hello from bird"
    Send a tweet

  bird 1234567890123456789 --json
    Read a tweet (ID or URL shorthand for `read`) and print JSON

Shortcuts
  bird <tweet-id-or-url> [--json]
    Shorthand for `bird read <tweet-id-or-url>`

JSON Output
  Add --json to: read, replies, thread, search, mentions, bookmarks, likes, following, followers, about, lists, list-timeline, user-tweets, query-ids
  Add --json-full to include raw API response in _raw field (tweet commands only)
  (Run bird <command> --help to see per-command flags.)


Config
  Reads ~/.config/bird/config.json5 and ./.birdrc.json5 (JSON5)
  Supports: chromeProfile, chromeProfileDir, firefoxProfile, cookieSource, cookieTimeoutMs, timeoutMs, quoteDepth

Env
  NO_COLOR, BIRD_TIMEOUT_MS, BIRD_COOKIE_TIMEOUT_MS, BIRD_QUOTE_DEPTH returns bird 0.8.0 CLI help. Also confirmed global install at /usr/local/lib/node_modules/@steipete/bird.

archive.title: Check VPN/Tailscale status on VPS
archive.description: SSH to 51.81.202.92: tailscale/tailscaled binaries not present; systemd unit tailscaled.service not found;  command not found; no docker containers related to tailscale; journalctl has no tailscaled logs. Conclusion: Tailscale is not installed/running on VPS, so VPN connection prompt is unrelated (it’s the noVNC basic-auth on :6900).

archive.title: Inventory existing remote access/VPN on VPS
archive.description: SSH inventory: No OpenVPN/WireGuard/Tailscale/IPSec packages or running services found. Remote access is via exposed ports: SSH 22, direct TigerVNC on 5905, noVNC via websockify serving /usr/share/novnc on 6080 -> localhost:5905, plus nginx listening on 6090 (likely virtual-host/proxy; returns 400 without proper Host header). Coolify/Traefik proxy on 80/443/8080. RustDesk server containers exposed on 21115-21119. UFW allows 5905/6080/6090/80/443/22/18789. No listener on 6900 currently, so prior :6900 prompt likely from different/old service or different host/port.

archive.title: Set up Tailscale + lock down public VNC
archive.description: Tailscale installed and authenticated successfully. VPS now online in tailnet as 100.110.172.52 (IPv6 fd7a:115c:a1e0::1501:ac9c). Locked down firewall: removed public UFW allows for 5905/6080/6090 and re-added allows only from Tailscale CGNAT range 100.64.0.0/10. Public SSH(22) and web ports (80/443/8080) unchanged. Next: user should connect VNC/noVNC using 100.110.172.52; optionally stop exposing noVNC entirely or bind VNC to localhost only.

archive.title: Fix VNC password/auth for TigerVNC
archive.description: Investigated TigerVNC auth: VNC server uses password file; hashes of /home/ubuntu/.vnc/passwd and /tmp/tigervnc*/passwd matched. Likely client incompatibility with TLSVnc/VeNCrypt. Updated systemd unit /etc/systemd/system/vncserver@.service ExecStart to force  (no TLS), reloaded daemon and restarted vncserver@5. Xtigervnc now reports -SecurityTypes VncAuth only. Ask user to retry connecting via Tailscale IP 100.110.172.52:5905 with same password.

archive.title: Review Android chat noise filtering port
archive.description: Reviewed Android commit 0dbb9c6 (ChatScreen.isSystemNoise additions for markdown file dumps + grep output patterns). Logic is reasonable and low-risk, but introduces redundant/duplicated filters (same # length>500 rule and grep/extension regex already exist later), and uses inline Regex(...) allocations per call. Recommend refactor: consolidate duplicates, precompile regex patterns (companion object / top-level vals), and tighten the \d+[-:].*\.ext pattern to reduce false positives (e.g., file names starting with digits). No functional blocker found.

archive.title: Refactor Android isSystemNoise regex + dedupe
archive.description: Implemented cleanup in ChatScreen.isSystemNoise: removed duplicated markdown/grep blocks added by 0dbb9c6, introduced precompiled Regex constants (NOISE_GREP_FILE_LINE_REGEX, NOISE_GREP_CODE_LINE_REGEX), tightened file-line pattern to require : or - after line number and word boundary on extension, replaced inline Regex allocations with constant usage. Commit 7f61862 pushed to main. Note: local container lacks Java toolchain (JAVA_HOME missing) so could not run Gradle compile here; change is syntactically straightforward.

archive.title: Android: Google Flash voice-friendly TTS
archive.description: Checked Android 'Voice-Friendly Mode' -> Gemini Flash implementation. It requires selecting Gemini Flash provider in Settings and saving a Gemini API key (AI Studio / Generative Language API). Code fix: updated Gemini request to use recommended header x-goog-api-key (and added Accept: application/json) instead of URL query param to improve reliability and avoid key in URL. Commit: 1d0e5c0 (MainViewModel.convertToVoiceFriendlyGemini). Next: user should test and share logcat lines containing 'Voice-friendly GEMINI' if still failing.

archive.title: Android: switch voice-friendly to Gemini 3.0 Flash
archive.description: Updated Android voice-friendly Gemini endpoint to Gemini Flash 3.0: gemini-3.0-flash:generateContent (kept x-goog-api-key header auth). Commit pushed: c4e246d.

archive.title: VPS: download SoLoStandBy 1.0.9 AAB from Drive
archive.description: Used Drive API download with OAuth bearer token (google-auth.py) over SSH to VPS. Saved file to /home/ubuntu/Downloads/app-release.aab (36M). Command: curl -H 'Authorization: Bearer <token>' https://www.googleapis.com/drive/v3/files/1lCDAONUolOM6R92h1x-P5gmwUGIrZqad?alt=media -o /home/ubuntu/Downloads/app-release.aab

archive.title: Android: filter browser snapshot 'generic [ref=]' noise
archive.description: Added Android noise filter for browser/DOM snapshot dumps (Playwright/aria snapshot style '- generic [ref=e]:' / 'progressbar' / 'banner' / 'cursor=pointer' / '/url:'). Patched ChatScreen.isSystemNoise to drop messages containing '[ref=' with these markers. Commit pushed: a9cc6de.

archive.title: Client-side: deterministic filtering of System/Cron/tool messages
archive.description: Implemented robust client-side filtering (no server changes) with user toggle. Android: added showSystemMessages pref (ui_show_system_messages) persisted in MainViewModel + SettingsScreen Debug section toggle. Updated ChatScreen.isSystemNoise(text, showSystemMessages) to deterministically hide 'System:' blocks by default, with exception to allow 'Cron (error):' to show; also passes toggle through ChatListView. Kept existing DOM snapshot '[ref=]' noise suppression. Commit: 69e4f55.

archive.title: Android: filter curl progress table noise
archive.description: Patched Android ChatScreen.isSystemNoise to drop curl progress table output (lines starting '% Total' with '% Received/% Xferd' and headers containing 'Average Speed/Time/Current'). Commit: ada73ba.

archive.title: Audit notification badge/NO messages
archive.description: Patched dashboard cross-session notifications to ignore [[read_ack]], NO, NO_REPLY and not count active-session messages (commit 1c61139). Updated cron jobs (90746f...) to delivery.mode=none and stricter NO_REPLY output. Completed 2026-02-10.

archive.title: Android: junk messages filtering regression
archive.description: Shipped multiple rounds of Android ChatScreen.isSystemNoise fixes: deterministic filtering of system/cron/tool messages, browser snapshot noise, curl progress tables, code dumps. Commits: 9502561, a9cc6de, 69e4f55, ada73ba + others. Debug toggle added. Completed 2026-02-10.

We’ll focus on **OpenClaw-native memory fixes**, not Redis/Qdrant.

### Most promising directions (without external DBs)
1. **Tune compaction + memoryFlush**
   - Ensure pre-compaction write is on and aggressive enough.
   - This is the #1 built-in guard against “forgetting after compaction.”

2. **Enforce memory write discipline in prompts**
   - Explicit rule: durable decisions/preferences must be written to `MEMORY.md` or `memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md`.
   - Add “if user says remember this → write it now.”

3. **Strengthen retrieval before memory questions**
   - Always run `memory_search` + `memory_get` for prior decisions/dates/preferences.
   - This is often the missing behavior, not missing storage.

4. **Enable/verify `session-memory` hook**
   - Captures context on `/new` resets into memory files so context doesn’t disappear between sessions.

5. **Use OpenClaw `memorySearch` config correctly**
   - Keep built-in plugin enabled.
   - Validate provider/API key, scope, paths, and indexing behavior so recall actually works.

6. **Compaction mode = `safeguard` + pruning settings**
   - Reduces context loss and minimizes noisy tool-output bloat that crowds out real memory signal.

---

- exact config keys to set,
- recommended values,
- verification checklist (`openclaw status`, test prompts, expected logs),
- and a phased rollout plan (safe → stronger).

Great find — this video is actually aligned with what we should prioritize (and it matches OpenClaw docs in the key areas).

## Insights to add to our report (non-Redis/Qdrant)

### 1) Memory flush before compaction is critical
**Why:** Prevents “I forgot right after one message” behavior when context compacts.  
**OpenClaw-native setting:** `agents.defaults.compaction.memoryFlush` (enable + tune threshold).  
This is likely the biggest win.

### 2) Vector/semantic memory search should be enabled and verified
The video calls this “semantic memory search”; OpenClaw docs call it vector memory search under built-in memory.  
**Key point:** It’s not enough to “turn on” — embeddings provider/API key + indexing must be healthy.

### 3) Auto-capture / explicit memory write behavior matters
The theme is: don’t rely on model implicit memory.  
You need behavior rules/prompting that force durable writes (`MEMORY.md` + daily logs) for preferences, decisions, constraints.

### 4) Session-memory hook helps with resets/new sessions
If you use `/new` flows, enabling `session-memory` preserves continuity snapshots into files.  
That closes a common “new session = memory gap” issue.

### 5) Hybrid retrieval improves exact recall
Video mentions hybrid search (keywords + semantic).  
In OpenClaw terms, this maps well to using:
- semantic `memory_search`
- targeted `memory_get`
- plus file naming/structure discipline for exact-key lookups (IDs, codes, vars).

### 6) Operational fix path should be part of rollout
Video mentions config errors and doctor repair; this is practical:
- validate config changes incrementally
- keep a rollback
- if broken, use `openclaw doctor --fix` and re-apply safely

---

## What this means for your implementation plan
For your report, we should rank this order:

1. **Compaction + memoryFlush tuning**
2. **Memory search provider/key/index verification**
3. **Prompt/behavior rules for durable writes**
4. **Session-memory hook**
5. **Retrieval discipline in agent instructions (always search/get before memory claims)**
6. **Optional advanced retrieval tuning**

If you want, next I’ll produce the final report as:
- **Problem symptoms → root causes → exact config/actions → validation tests → rollback plan**  
specific to your environment.

🔬 **DEEP RESEARCH REPORT: Fixing OpenClaw Memory Reliability (without Redis/Qdrant)**

## ⚡ Executive answer
Yes — there are strong OpenClaw-native ways to fix “forgetfulness,” and the most promising path is:  
1) tune **pre-compaction memory flush**,  
2) verify **vector memory search** is actually working (provider/index),  
3) enforce **memory write + recall discipline** in agent behavior, and  
4) enable **session-memory hook** for `/new` continuity.

---

## 📊 Confidence
**High** on the architecture and fix sequence (matches OpenClaw docs + video pattern).  
**Medium** on exact values for your environment until we run validation tests.

---

## ✅ Most promising solutions (ranked)

### 1) Enable/tune compaction memory flush (highest impact)
**Why:** Most “forgot right away” failures happen around compaction boundaries.  
**What to set:**
```json5
agents: {
  defaults: {
    compaction: {
      mode: "safeguard",
      reserveTokensFloor: 20000,
      memoryFlush: {
        enabled: true,
        softThresholdTokens: 4000,
        systemPrompt: "Session nearing compaction. Store durable memories now.",
        prompt: "Write lasting notes to memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md and MEMORY.md when appropriate. Reply NO_REPLY if nothing durable."
      }
    }
  }
}
```
Tune `softThresholdTokens` upward if you still lose context before flush occurs.

---

### 2) Make vector memory search actually operational
**Why:** “Enabled but not functioning” is common (missing embedding key/provider/index state).  
**Key checks:**
- `agents.defaults.memorySearch` configured (provider + model)
- embedding API key present (OpenAI/Gemini/Voyage/Mistral)
- memory backend not disabled (`plugins.slots.memory != "none"`)
- file paths include your actual memory files

Example baseline:
```json5
agents: {
  defaults: {
    memorySearch: {
      provider: "openai", // or gemini/voyage/mistral/local
      model: "text-embedding-3-small"
    }
  }
}
```

---

### 3) Enforce durable-write behavior in agent instructions
**Why:** Storage fails when agent isn’t consistently told what is “durable.”  
Add explicit rules in AGENTS/SOUL/system behavior:

- If user says “remember this” → write immediately
- Preferences/decisions/constraints → MEMORY.md
- Daily context/work log → memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md
- No “mental note” promises without file write

This reduces silent memory drift.

---

### 4) Enable session-memory hook for `/new` continuity
**Why:** New-session transitions can look like “amnesia.”  
Enable:
```bash
openclaw hooks enable session-memory
```
This captures recent context to memory files when resetting session.

---

### 5) Improve recall discipline (before answering memory questions)
**Why:** Retrieval isn’t automatic unless behavior enforces it.  
Policy:
- Before answers about prior decisions/preferences/dates/todos:
  1) `memory_search`
  2) `memory_get` on top hits
  3) answer with confidence and mention uncertainty if weak

This avoids hallucinated recall.

---

### 6) Use cleaner memory structure + optional hybrid strategy
Keep:
- `MEMORY.md` (curated long-term)

## ✅ Most promising solutions (ranked)

**Why:** Most “forgot right away” failures happen around compaction boundaries.

```json5
agents: {
  defaults: {
    compaction: {
      mode: "safeguard",
      reserveTokensFloor: 20000,
      memoryFlush: {
        enabled: true,
        softThresholdTokens: 4000,
        systemPrompt: "Session nearing compaction. Store durable memories now.",
        prompt: "Write lasting notes to memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md and MEMORY.md when appropriate. Reply NO_REPLY if nothing durable."
      }
    }
  }
}
```
Tune `softThresholdTokens` upward if you still lose context before flush occurs.

### 2) Make vector memory search actually operational
**Why:** “Enabled but not functioning” is common (missing embedding key/provider/index state).  
**Key checks:**
- `agents.defaults.memorySearch` configured (provider + model)

- file paths include your actual memory files

Example baseline:
```json5
agents: {
  defaults: {
    memorySearch: {
      provider: "openai", // or gemini/voyage/mistral/local
      model: "text-embedding-3-small"
    }
  }
}
```

---

### 3) Enforce durable-write behavior in agent instructions
**Why:** Storage fails when agent isn’t consistently told what is “durable.”  
Add explicit rules in AGENTS/SOUL/system behavior:

- If user says “remember this” → write immediately
- Preferences/decisions/constraints → MEMORY.md
- Daily context/work log → memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md
- No “mental note” promises without file write

This reduces silent memory drift.

---

### 4) Enable session-memory hook for `/new` continuity
**Why:** New-session transitions can look like “amnesia.”  
Enable:
```bash
openclaw hooks enable session-memory
```
This captures recent context to memory files when resetting session.

**Why:** Retrieval isn’t automatic unless behavior enforces it.  
Policy:
- Before answers about prior decisions/preferences/dates/todos:
  1) `memory_search`
  2) `memory_get` on top hits
  3) answer with confidence and mention uncertainty if weak

This avoids hallucinated recall.

what do the smoke hooks do?

“Smoke hooks” are tiny sanity checks/pings to confirm a route is alive.

In your case those `codex-smoke-*` messages are basically:
- **connectivity checks** (can Dev receive/respond)
- **post-script checks** (did a trigger/script run end-to-end)
- **quick health probes** after force/restart events

They don’t do feature work — they just verify the pipeline is still working.

If you disable them:
- ✅ less chat noise
- ❌ less early warning when routing/session wiring breaks

If you want, I can keep only one minimal smoke check (quiet mode) instead of full noise.
we can disable
Perfect — we’ll disable them.

But our biggest issue is still that conversation was between me and Halo and you somehow received it. I was talking to Halo about the codex smoke test, and it went to you as well. WE HAVE TO FIGURE OUT WHY OUR MESSAGES ARE BLEEDING

You’re absolutely right — and I have a solid root-cause finding now.

### What’s causing the “bleed”
It’s **not random cross-agent memory** and not Android.  
It’s coming from the dashboard test path using the client identity **`gateway-client`**.

Evidence:
- Your inbound metadata here shows `sender_id: "gateway-client"`.
- Same `codex-smoke* / codex-connectivity-check*` strings appear across multiple agent sessions at the same times.
- Dashboard code/history references a test harness path (`sendTestMessage`, health-check/test sessions) tied to `gateway-client`.

So what looked like “Halo convo leaking to Dev” is actually **test injections entering shared chat routing**, not true Halo↔Dev transcript merge.

### Immediate containment (what I recommend now)
1. **Hard-disable smoke/test injectors** in dashboard runtime (not just “don’t use”).
2. **Gate test sends behind explicit debug flag** (off by default in prod).
3. **Drop `codex-smoke*` / `codex-connectivity-check*` at ingress** as a safety filter.
4. Keep model health checks isolated only to `health-check-*` sessions.

If you want, I’ll apply this containment patch next so this noise cannot hit agent chats again.
yes
I’m applying the containment patch now. I need to stash local dashboard WIP first so I can sync cleanly, then I’ll patch and push the smoke-hook guards.

Done — I applied containment and pushed.

### ✅ Patch shipped
Repo: `solobot-dashboard`  
Commit: `927553d`

### What it does
1. **Blocks smoke-hook style messages** from dashboard sends by default:
   - `codex-smoke*`
   - `codex-connectivity-check*`
   - `codex-direct-*`
   - `codex-post-script-smoke*`

2. **Hard-gates test sends** (`sendTestMessage`) so they only run in `health-check-*` sessions unless explicitly overridden.

### Effect
This prevents dashboard-origin smoke/test strings from being injected into normal agent chats (Dev/Halo/etc.) in production mode.

If needed for debugging later, we can explicitly re-enable with:
- `window.__ALLOW_SMOKE_HOOKS__ = true` (or `localStorage.allow_smoke_hooks = "true"`)

Also: I had to stash local uncommitted dashboard WIP to sync cleanly before patching; I left that stash intact (`pre-smoke-hook-containment`).

Yep — great logs, and they show the issue clearly. I patched Android and pushed.

### What your logs show
- Message send started, then:
  - `node.event failed: request timeout`
  - `WebSocket onFailure: Broken pipe`
- After reconnect, app reloads history and does a full replace:
  - your local just-sent user message gets overwritten if it didn’t reach server yet.
- Also, Android was bulk-subscribing to many sessions and getting:
  - `unauthorized role: operator` repeatedly
  - that adds noisy failures/timeouts during reconnect windows.

---

### ✅ Fixes pushed (Android)
Commit: **`cd65807`** (`SoLoBot-Android` main)

1. **Disabled bulk cross-session subscribe on Android**
   - prevents unauthorized-role spam and reduces timeout pressure.
2. **Preserve pending local user messages on history replace**
   - if reconnect happens before gateway confirms send, your recent local message won’t disappear immediately.

---

### What to do now
1. Pull latest Android app build from `main`.
2. Reproduce by sending a test message during unstable network/reconnect.
3. You should now see:
   - fewer timeout cascades
   - no immediate disappearance of freshly sent message during history refresh.

If it still fails to actually deliver (not just visibility), I’ll add a retry queue for timed-out sends next.

Quick confirm: what exactly do you want disabled (agent visibility toggles, codex smoke hooks, or something else)?
what do the smoke hooks do?

“Smoke hooks” are tiny sanity checks/pings to confirm a route is alive.

In your case those `codex-smoke-*` messages are basically:
- **connectivity checks** (can Dev receive/respond)
- **post-script checks** (did a trigger/script run end-to-end)
- **quick health probes** after force/restart events

They don’t do feature work — they just verify the pipeline is still working.

If you disable them:
- ✅ less chat noise
- ❌ less early warning when routing/session wiring breaks

If you want, I can keep only one minimal smoke check (quiet mode) instead of full noise.
we can disable
Perfect — we’ll disable them.

But our biggest issue is still that conversation was between me and Halo and you somehow received it. I was talking to Halo about the codex smoke test, and it went to you as well. WE HAVE TO FIGURE OUT WHY OUR MESSAGES ARE BLEEDING

You’re absolutely right — and I have a solid root-cause finding now.

### What’s causing the “bleed”
It’s **not random cross-agent memory** and not Android.  
It’s coming from the dashboard test path using the client identity **`gateway-client`**.

Evidence:
- Your inbound metadata here shows `sender_id: "gateway-client"`.
- Same `codex-smoke* / codex-connectivity-check*` strings appear across multiple agent sessions at the same times.
- Dashboard code/history references a test harness path (`sendTestMessage`, health-check/test sessions) tied to `gateway-client`.

So what looked like “Halo convo leaking to Dev�� is actually **test injections entering shared chat routing**, not true Halo↔Dev transcript merge.

### Immediate containment (what I recommend now)
1. **Hard-disable smoke/test injectors** in dashboard runtime (not just “don’t use”).
2. **Gate test sends behind explicit debug flag** (off by default in prod).
3. **Drop `codex-smoke*` / `codex-connectivity-check*` at ingress** as a safety filter.
4. Keep model health checks isolated only to `health-check-*` sessions.

If you want, I’ll apply this containment patch next so this noise cannot hit agent chats again.
yes
I’m applying the containment patch now. I need to stash local dashboard WIP first so I can sync cleanly, then I’ll patch and push the smoke-hook guards.

Done — I applied containment and pushed.

### ✅ Patch shipped
Repo: `solobot-dashboard`  
Commit: `927553d`

### What it does
1. **Blocks smoke-hook style messages** from dashboard sends by default:
   - `codex-smoke*`
   - `codex-connectivity-check*`
   - `codex-direct-*`
   - `codex-post-script-smoke*`

2. **Hard-gates test sends** (`sendTestMessage`) so they only run in `health-check-*` sessions unless explicitly overridden.

### Effect
This prevents dashboard-origin smoke/test strings from being injected into normal agent chats (Dev/Halo/etc.) in production mode.

If needed for debugging later, we can explicitly re-enable with:
- `window.__ALLOW_SMOKE_HOOKS__ = true` (or `localStorage.allow_smoke_hooks = "true"`)

Also: I had to stash local uncommitted dashboard WIP to sync cleanly before patching; I left that stash intact (`pre-smoke-hook-containment`).

Yep — great logs, and they show the issue clearly. I patched Android and pushed.

### What your logs show
- Message send started, then:
  - `node.event failed: request timeout`
  - `WebSocket onFailure: Broken pipe`
- After reconnect, app reloads history and does a full replace:
  - your local just-sent user message gets overwritten if it didn’t reach server yet.
- Also, Android was bulk-subscribing to many sessions and getting:
  - `unauthorized role: operator` repeatedly
  - that adds noisy failures/timeouts during reconnect windows.

---

### ✅ Fixes pushed (Android)
Commit: **`cd65807`** (`SoLoBot-Android` main)

1. **Disabled bulk cross-session subscribe on Android**
   - prevents unauthorized-role spam and reduces timeout pressure.
2. **Preserve pending local user messages on history replace**
   - if reconnect happens before gateway confirms send, your recent local message won’t disappear immediately.

---

### What to do now
1. Pull latest Android app build from `main`.
2. Reproduce by sending a test message during unstable network/reconnect.
3. You should now see:
   - fewer timeout cascades
   - no immediate disappearance of freshly sent message during history refresh.

If it still fails to actually deliver (not just visibility), I’ll add a retry queue for timed-out sends next.

what do the smoke hooks do?

“Smoke hooks” are tiny sanity checks/pings to confirm a route is alive.

In your case those `codex-smoke-*` messages are basically:
- **connectivity checks** (can Dev receive/respond)
- **post-script checks** (did a trigger/script run end-to-end)
- **quick health probes** after force/restart events

They don’t do feature work — they just verify the pipeline is still working.

If you disable them:
- ✅ less chat noise
- ❌ less early warning when routing/session wiring breaks

If you want, I can keep only one minimal smoke check (quiet mode) instead of full noise.

You’re absolutely right — and I have a solid root-cause finding now.

### What’s causing the “bleed”
It’s **not random cross-agent memory** and not Android.  
It’s coming from the dashboard test path using the client identity **`gateway-client`**.

Evidence:
- Your inbound metadata here shows `sender_id: "gateway-client"`.
- Same `codex-smoke* / codex-connectivity-check*` strings appear across multiple agent sessions at the same times.
- Dashboard code/history references a test harness path (`sendTestMessage`, health-check/test sessions) tied to `gateway-client`.

So what looked like “Halo convo leaking to Dev” is actually **test injections entering shared chat routing**, not true Halo↔Dev transcript merge.

### Immediate containment (what I recommend now)
1. **Hard-disable smoke/test injectors** in dashboard runtime (not just “don’t use”).
2. **Gate test sends behind explicit debug flag** (off by default in prod).
3. **Drop `codex-smoke*` / `codex-connectivity-check*` at ingress** as a safety filter.
4. Keep model health checks isolated only to `health-check-*` sessions.

If you want, I’ll apply this containment patch next so this noise cannot hit agent chats again.
yes
I’m applying the containment patch now. I need to stash local dashboard WIP first so I can sync cleanly, then I’ll patch and push the smoke-hook guards.

Done — I applied containment and pushed.

### ✅ Patch shipped
Repo: `solobot-dashboard`  
Commit: `927553d`

### What it does
1. **Blocks smoke-hook style messages** from dashboard sends by default:
   - `codex-smoke*`
   - `codex-connectivity-check*`
   - `codex-direct-*`
   - `codex-post-script-smoke*`

2. **Hard-gates test sends** (`sendTestMessage`) so they only run in `health-check-*` sessions unless explicitly overridden.

### Effect
This prevents dashboard-origin smoke/test strings from being injected into normal agent chats (Dev/Halo/etc.) in production mode.

If needed for debugging later, we can explicitly re-enable with:
- `window.__ALLOW_SMOKE_HOOKS__ = true` (or `localStorage.allow_smoke_hooks = "true"`)

Also: I had to stash local uncommitted dashboard WIP to sync cleanly before patching; I left that stash intact (`pre-smoke-hook-containment`).

Yep — great logs, and they show the issue clearly. I patched Android and pushed.

### What your logs show
- Message send started, then:
  - `node.event failed: request timeout`
  - `WebSocket onFailure: Broken pipe`
- After reconnect, app reloads history and does a full replace:
  - your local just-sent user message gets overwritten if it didn’t reach server yet.
- Also, Android was bulk-subscribing to many sessions and getting:
  - `unauthorized role: operator` repeatedly
  - that adds noisy failures/timeouts during reconnect windows.

---

### ✅ Fixes pushed (Android)
Commit: **`cd65807`** (`SoLoBot-Android` main)

1. **Disabled bulk cross-session subscribe on Android**
   - prevents unauthorized-role spam and reduces timeout pressure.
2. **Preserve pending local user messages on history replace**
   - if reconnect happens before gateway confirms send, your recent local message won’t disappear immediately.

---

### What to do now
1. Pull latest Android app build from `main`.
2. Reproduce by sending a test message during unstable network/reconnect.
3. You should now see:
   - fewer timeout cascades
   - no immediate disappearance of freshly sent message during history refresh.

If it still fails to actually deliver (not just visibility), I’ll add a retry queue for timed-out sends next.

## What the video implemented (high level)
From the transcript, the approach was:

1. **Redis = short-term memory**
   - heartbeat periodically stores full conversation into Redis

2. **Qdrant = long-term memory**
   - scheduled job moves Redis content into Qdrant (dedup/smart ingest), then clears Redis

3. **OpenClaw native memory still kept**
   - markdown memory flow remains in parallel

So the core pattern is **dual memory system**: transient memory store + vector memory store + scheduled promotion.

---

## What your dashboard code currently has
In `solobot-dashboard`, memory features I found are mostly:

- file-based memory browsing/editing APIs:
  - `/api/memory`
  - `/api/memory/<file>`
  - memory versions/restore/meta ack
- UI around those file APIs (`docs-hub-memory-files.js`, `js/memory*.js`)
- chat send path via `chat.send` in `gateway-client.js`

What I **did not** find in dashboard runtime code:

- Redis integration for conversational memory
- Qdrant integration for semantic long-term memory
- memory retrieval in chat send path (`memory_search`/`memory_get`) before `chat.send`
- vector retrieval pipeline tied into prompts

### Most promising directions (without external DBs)
1. **Tune compaction + memoryFlush**
   - Ensure pre-compaction write is on and aggressive enough.
   - This is the #1 built-in guard against “forgetting after compaction.”

2. **Enforce memory write discipline in prompts**
   - Explicit rule: durable decisions/preferences must be written to `MEMORY.md` or `memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md`.
   - Add “if user says remember this → write it now.”

3. **Strengthen retrieval before memory questions**
   - Always run `memory_search` + `memory_get` for prior decisions/dates/preferences.
   - This is often the missing behavior, not missing storage.

4. **Enable/verify `session-memory` hook**
   - Captures context on `/new` resets into memory files so context doesn’t disappear between sessions.

5. **Use OpenClaw `memorySearch` config correctly**
   - Keep built-in plugin enabled.
   - Validate provider/API key, scope, paths, and indexing behavior so recall actually works.

6. **Compaction mode = `safeguard` + pruning settings**
   - Reduces context loss and minimizes noisy tool-output bloat that crowds out real memory signal.

## Insights to add to our report (non-Redis/Qdrant)

### 1) Memory flush before compaction is critical
**Why:** Prevents “I forgot right after one message” behavior when context compacts.  
**OpenClaw-native setting:** `agents.defaults.compaction.memoryFlush` (enable + tune threshold).  
This is likely the biggest win.

### 2) Vector/semantic memory search should be enabled and verified
The video calls this “semantic memory search”; OpenClaw docs call it vector memory search under built-in memory.  
**Key point:** It’s not enough to “turn on” — embeddings provider/API key + indexing must be healthy.

### 3) Auto-capture / explicit memory write behavior matters
The theme is: don’t rely on model implicit memory.  
You need behavior rules/prompting that force durable writes (`MEMORY.md` + daily logs) for preferences, decisions, constraints.

### 4) Session-memory hook helps with resets/new sessions
If you use `/new` flows, enabling `session-memory` preserves continuity snapshots into files.  
That closes a common “new session = memory gap” issue.

### 5) Hybrid retrieval improves exact recall
Video mentions hybrid search (keywords + semantic).  
In OpenClaw terms, this maps well to using:
- semantic `memory_search`
- targeted `memory_get`
- plus file naming/structure discipline for exact-key lookups (IDs, codes, vars).

### 6) Operational fix path should be part of rollout
Video mentions config errors and doctor repair; this is practical:
- validate config changes incrementally
- keep a rollback
- if broken, use `openclaw doctor --fix` and re-apply safely

🔬 **DEEP RESEARCH REPORT: Fixing OpenClaw Memory Reliability (without Redis/Qdrant)**

## ⚡ Executive answer
Yes — there are strong OpenClaw-native ways to fix “forgetfulness,” and the most promising path is:  
1) tune **pre-compaction memory flush**,  
2) verify **vector memory search** is actually working (provider/index),  
3) enforce **memory write + recall discipline** in agent behavior, and  
4) enable **session-memory hook** for `/new` continuity.

---

## 📊 Confidence
**High** on the architecture and fix sequence (matches OpenClaw docs + video pattern).  
**Medium** on exact values for your environment until we run validation tests.

---

## ✅ Most promising solutions (ranked)

### 1) Enable/tune compaction memory flush (highest impact)
**Why:** Most ��forgot right away” failures happen around compaction boundaries.  
**What to set:**
```json5
agents: {
  defaults: {
    compaction: {
      mode: "safeguard",
      reserveTokensFloor: 20000,
      memoryFlush: {
        enabled: true,
        softThresholdTokens: 4000,
        systemPrompt: "Session nearing compaction. Store durable memories now.",
        prompt: "Write lasting notes to memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md and MEMORY.md when appropriate. Reply NO_REPLY if nothing durable."
      }
    }
  }
}
```
Tune `softThresholdTokens` upward if you still lose context before flush occurs.

---

### 2) Make vector memory search actually operational
**Why:** “Enabled but not functioning” is common (missing embedding key/provider/index state).  
**Key checks:**
- `agents.defaults.memorySearch` configured (provider + model)
- embedding API key present (OpenAI/Gemini/Voyage/Mistral)
- memory backend not disabled (`plugins.slots.memory != "none"`)
- file paths include your actual memory files

Example baseline:
```json5
agents: {
  defaults: {
    memorySearch: {
      provider: "openai", // or gemini/voyage/mistral/local
      model: "text-embedding-3-small"
    }
  }
}
```

---

### 3) Enforce durable-write behavior in agent instructions
**Why:** Storage fails when agent isn’t consistently told what is “durable.”  
Add explicit rules in AGENTS/SOUL/system behavior:

- If user says “remember this” → write immediately
- Preferences/decisions/constraints → MEMORY.md
- Daily context/work log → memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md
- No “mental note” promises without file write

This reduces silent memory drift.

---

### 4) Enable session-memory hook for `/new` continuity
**Why:** New-session transitions can look like “amnesia.”  
Enable:
```bash
openclaw hooks enable session-memory
```
This captures recent context to memory files when resetting session.

---

### 5) Improve recall discipline (before answering memory questions)
**Why:** Retrieval isn’t automatic unless behavior enforces it.  
Policy:
- Before answers about prior decisions/preferences/dates/todos:
  1) `memory_search`
  2) `memory_get` on top hits
  3) answer with confidence and mention uncertainty if weak

This avoids hallucinated recall.

---

### 6) Use cleaner memory structure + optional hybrid strategy
Keep:
- `MEMORY.md` (curated long-term)
- `memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md` (daily append logs)

For exact recall (IDs/error codes), supplement semantic search with explicit keyword pathing and consistent naming.

---

## 🧪 Validation plan (must pass)

### A) Compaction retention test
1. Feed 20–40 turns with key facts sprinkled in  
2. Force/trigger compaction (`/compact`)  
3. Ask for older facts  
✅ Pass if recovered with high accuracy

### B) “Remember this” durability test
1. Tell agent 5 explicit preferences  
2. Start new session or force compaction  
3. Ask preferences  
✅ Pass if all recovered

### C) Hook continuity test
1. In session A, create unique context  
2. `/new`  
3. Ask what was preserved  
✅ Pass if context snapshot available via memory files

### D) Embedding/index health test
1. Write a rare phrase in memory file  
2. `memory_search` with paraphrased query  
✅ Pass if phrase retrieved semantically

---

## 🚨 Common failure modes to watch
- Embedding key missing/expired
- Memory plugin disabled
- memoryFlush enabled but threshold too late
- Agent writes only summaries, not durable facts
- Uses memory files in dashboard UI but no retrieval in chat behavior

---

## 📌 Recommended rollout (safe)
1. Apply compaction+flush config  
2. Verify memorySearch provider/key/index  
3. Enable session-memory hook  
4. Strengthen instruction rules  
5. Run the 4 validation tests above  
6. Tune thresholds based on failures

---

## What the video implemented (high level)
From the transcript, the approach was:

1. **Redis = short-term memory**
   - heartbeat periodically stores full conversation into Redis

2. **Qdrant = long-term memory**
   - scheduled job moves Redis content into Qdrant (dedup/smart ingest), then clears Redis

3. **OpenClaw native memory still kept**
   - markdown memory flow remains in parallel

So the core pattern is **dual memory system**: transient memory store + vector memory store + scheduled promotion.

- vector retrieval pipeline tied into prompts

We’ll focus on **OpenClaw-native memory fixes**, not Redis/Qdrant.

### Most promising directions (without external DBs)
1. **Tune compaction + memoryFlush**
   - Ensure pre-compaction write is on and aggressive enough.
   - This is the #1 built-in guard against “forgetting after compaction.”

2. **Enforce memory write discipline in prompts**
   - Explicit rule: durable decisions/preferences must be written to `MEMORY.md` or `memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md`.
   - Add “if user says remember this → write it now.”

3. **Strengthen retrieval before memory questions**
   - Always run `memory_search` + `memory_get` for prior decisions/dates/preferences.
   - This is often the missing behavior, not missing storage.

4. **Enable/verify `session-memory` hook**
   - Captures context on `/new` resets into memory files so context doesn’t disappear between sessions.

5. **Use OpenClaw `memorySearch` config correctly**
   - Keep built-in plugin enabled.
   - Validate provider/API key, scope, paths, and indexing behavior so recall actually works.

6. **Compaction mode = `safeguard` + pruning settings**
   - Reduces context loss and minimizes noisy tool-output bloat that crowds out real memory signal.

## Insights to add to our report (non-Redis/Qdrant)

### 1) Memory flush before compaction is critical
**Why:** Prevents “I forgot right after one message” behavior when context compacts.  
**OpenClaw-native setting:** `agents.defaults.compaction.memoryFlush` (enable + tune threshold).  
This is likely the biggest win.

### 2) Vector/semantic memory search should be enabled and verified
The video calls this “semantic memory search”; OpenClaw docs call it vector memory search under built-in memory.  
**Key point:** It’s not enough to “turn on” — embeddings provider/API key + indexing must be healthy.

### 3) Auto-capture / explicit memory write behavior matters
The theme is: don’t rely on model implicit memory.  
You need behavior rules/prompting that force durable writes (`MEMORY.md` + daily logs) for preferences, decisions, constraints.

### 4) Session-memory hook helps with resets/new sessions
If you use `/new` flows, enabling `session-memory` preserves continuity snapshots into files.  
That closes a common “new session = memory gap” issue.

### 5) Hybrid retrieval improves exact recall
Video mentions hybrid search (keywords + semantic).  
In OpenClaw terms, this maps well to using:
- semantic `memory_search`
- targeted `memory_get`
- plus file naming/structure discipline for exact-key lookups (IDs, codes, vars).

### 6) Operational fix path should be part of rollout
Video mentions config errors and doctor repair; this is practical:
- validate config changes incrementally
- keep a rollback
- if broken, use `openclaw doctor --fix` and re-apply safely

🔬 **DEEP RESEARCH REPORT: Fixing OpenClaw Memory Reliability (without Redis/Qdrant)**

## ⚡ Executive answer
Yes — there are strong OpenClaw-native ways to fix “forgetfulness,” and the most promising path is:  
1) tune **pre-compaction memory flush**,  
2) verify **vector memory search** is actually working (provider/index),  
3) enforce **memory write + recall discipline** in agent behavior, and  
4) enable **session-memory hook** for `/new` continuity.

---

## 📊 Confidence
**High** on the architecture and fix sequence (matches OpenClaw docs + video pattern).  
**Medium** on exact values for your environment until we run validation tests.

---

## ✅ Most promising solutions (ranked)

### 1) Enable/tune compaction memory flush (highest impact)
**Why:** Most “forgot right away” failures happen around compaction boundaries.  
**What to set:**
```json5
agents: {
  defaults: {
    compaction: {
      mode: "safeguard",
      reserveTokensFloor: 20000,
      memoryFlush: {
        enabled: true,
        softThresholdTokens: 4000,
        systemPrompt: "Session nearing compaction. Store durable memories now.",
        prompt: "Write lasting notes to memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md and MEMORY.md when appropriate. Reply NO_REPLY if nothing durable."
      }
    }
  }
}
```
Tune `softThresholdTokens` upward if you still lose context before flush occurs.

---

### 2) Make vector memory search actually operational
**Why:** “Enabled but not functioning” is common (missing embedding key/provider/index state).  
**Key checks:**
- `agents.defaults.memorySearch` configured (provider + model)
- embedding API key present (OpenAI/Gemini/Voyage/Mistral)
- memory backend not disabled (`plugins.slots.memory != "none"`)
- file paths include your actual memory files

Example baseline:
```json5
agents: {
  defaults: {
    memorySearch: {
      provider: "openai", // or gemini/voyage/mistral/local
      model: "text-embedding-3-small"
    }
  }
}
```

---

### 3) Enforce durable-write behavior in agent instructions
**Why:** Storage fails when agent isn’t consistently told what is “durable.”  
Add explicit rules in AGENTS/SOUL/system behavior:

- If user says “remember this” → write immediately
- Preferences/decisions/constraints → MEMORY.md
- Daily context/work log → memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md
- No “mental note” promises without file write

This reduces silent memory drift.

---

### 4) Enable session-memory hook for `/new` continuity
**Why:** New-session transitions can look like “amnesia.”  
Enable:
```bash
openclaw hooks enable session-memory
```
This captures recent context to memory files when resetting session.

---

### 5) Improve recall discipline (before answering memory questions)
**Why:** Retrieval isn’t automatic unless behavior enforces it.  
Policy:
- Before answers about prior decisions/preferences/dates/todos:
  1) `memory_search`
  2) `memory_get` on top hits
  3) answer with confidence and mention uncertainty if weak

This avoids hallucinated recall.

---

### 6) Use cleaner memory structure + optional hybrid strategy
Keep:
- `MEMORY.md` (curated long-term)
- `memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md` (daily append logs)

For exact recall (IDs/error codes), supplement semantic search with explicit keyword pathing and consistent naming.

---

## 🧪 Validation plan (must pass)

### A) Compaction retention test
1. Feed 20–40 turns with key facts sprinkled in  
2. Force/trigger compaction (`/compact`)  
3. Ask for older facts  
✅ Pass if recovered with high accuracy

### B) “Remember this” durability test
1. Tell agent 5 explicit preferences  
2. Start new session or force compaction  
3. Ask preferences  
✅ Pass if all recovered

### C) Hook continuity test
1. In session A, create unique context  
2. `/new`  
3. Ask what was preserved  
✅ Pass if context snapshot available via memory files

### D) Embedding/index health test
1. Write a rare phrase in memory file  
2. `memory_search` with paraphrased query  
✅ Pass if phrase retrieved semantically

---

## 🚨 Common failure modes to watch
- Embedding key missing/expired
- Memory plugin disabled
- memoryFlush enabled but threshold too late
- Agent writes only summaries, not durable facts
- Uses memory files in dashboard UI but no retrieval in chat behavior

---

## 📌 Recommended rollout (safe)
1. Apply compaction+flush config  
2. Verify memorySearch provider/key/index  
3. Enable session-memory hook  
4. Strengthen instruction rules  
5. Run the 4 validation tests above  
6. Tune thresholds based on failures

## What the video implemented (high level)
From the transcript, the approach was:

1. **Redis = short-term memory**
   - heartbeat periodically stores full conversation into Redis

2. **Qdrant = long-term memory**
   - scheduled job moves Redis content into Qdrant (dedup/smart ingest), then clears Redis

3. **OpenClaw native memory still kept**
   - markdown memory flow remains in parallel

So the core pattern is **dual memory system**: transient memory store + vector memory store + scheduled promotion.

   - Captures context on `/new` resets into memory files so context doesn’t disappear between sessions.

5. **Use OpenClaw `memorySearch` config correctly**
   - Keep built-in plugin enabled.
   - Validate provider/API key, scope, paths, and indexing behavior so recall actually works.

   - Reduces context loss and minimizes noisy tool-output bloat that crowds out real memory signal.

## Insights to add to our report (non-Redis/Qdrant)

### 1) Memory flush before compaction is critical
**Why:** Prevents “I forgot right after one message” behavior when context compacts.  
**OpenClaw-native setting:** `agents.defaults.compaction.memoryFlush` (enable + tune threshold).  
This is likely the biggest win.

### 2) Vector/semantic memory search should be enabled and verified
The video calls this “semantic memory search”; OpenClaw docs call it vector memory search under built-in memory.  
**Key point:** It’s not enough to “turn on” — embeddings provider/API key + indexing must be healthy.

### 3) Auto-capture / explicit memory write behavior matters
The theme is: don’t rely on model implicit memory.  
You need behavior rules/prompting that force durable writes (`MEMORY.md` + daily logs) for preferences, decisions, constraints.

### 4) Session-memory hook helps with resets/new sessions
If you use `/new` flows, enabling `session-memory` preserves continuity snapshots into files.  
That closes a common “new session = memory gap” issue.

### 5) Hybrid retrieval improves exact recall
Video mentions hybrid search (keywords + semantic).  
In OpenClaw terms, this maps well to using:
- semantic `memory_search`
- targeted `memory_get`
- plus file naming/structure discipline for exact-key lookups (IDs, codes, vars).

### 6) Operational fix path should be part of rollout
Video mentions config errors and doctor repair; this is practical:
- validate config changes incrementally
- keep a rollback
- if broken, use `openclaw doctor --fix` and re-apply safely

🔬 **DEEP RESEARCH REPORT: Fixing OpenClaw Memory Reliability (without Redis/Qdrant)**

## ⚡ Executive answer
Yes — there are strong OpenClaw-native ways to fix “forgetfulness,” and the most promising path is:  
1) tune **pre-compaction memory flush**,  
2) verify **vector memory search** is actually working (provider/index),  
3) enforce **memory write + recall discipline** in agent behavior, and  
4) enable **session-memory hook** for `/new` continuity.

---

## 📊 Confidence
**High** on the architecture and fix sequence (matches OpenClaw docs + video pattern).  
**Medium** on exact values for your environment until we run validation tests.

---

## ✅ Most promising solutions (ranked)

### 1) Enable/tune compaction memory flush (highest impact)
**Why:** Most “forgot right away” failures happen around compaction boundaries.  
**What to set:**
```json5
agents: {
  defaults: {
    compaction: {
      mode: "safeguard",
      reserveTokensFloor: 20000,
      memoryFlush: {
        enabled: true,
        softThresholdTokens: 4000,
        systemPrompt: "Session nearing compaction. Store durable memories now.",
        prompt: "Write lasting notes to memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md and MEMORY.md when appropriate. Reply NO_REPLY if nothing durable."
      }
    }
  }
}
```
Tune `softThresholdTokens` upward if you still lose context before flush occurs.

---

### 2) Make vector memory search actually operational
**Why:** “Enabled but not functioning” is common (missing embedding key/provider/index state).  
**Key checks:**
- `agents.defaults.memorySearch` configured (provider + model)
- embedding API key present (OpenAI/Gemini/Voyage/Mistral)
- memory backend not disabled (`plugins.slots.memory != "none"`)
- file paths include your actual memory files

Example baseline:
```json5
agents: {
  defaults: {
    memorySearch: {
      provider: "openai", // or gemini/voyage/mistral/local
      model: "text-embedding-3-small"
    }
  }
}
```

---

### 3) Enforce durable-write behavior in agent instructions
**Why:** Storage fails when agent isn’t consistently told what is “durable.”  
Add explicit rules in AGENTS/SOUL/system behavior:

- If user says “remember this” → write immediately
- Preferences/decisions/constraints → MEMORY.md
- Daily context/work log → memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md
- No “mental note” promises without file write

This reduces silent memory drift.

---

### 4) Enable session-memory hook for `/new` continuity
**Why:** New-session transitions can look like “amnesia.”  
Enable:
```bash
openclaw hooks enable session-memory
```
This captures recent context to memory files when resetting session.

---

### 5) Improve recall discipline (before answering memory questions)
**Why:** Retrieval isn’t automatic unless behavior enforces it.  
Policy:
- Before answers about prior decisions/preferences/dates/todos:
  1) `memory_search`
  2) `memory_get` on top hits
  3) answer with confidence and mention uncertainty if weak

This avoids hallucinated recall.

---

### 6) Use cleaner memory structure + optional hybrid strategy
Keep:
- `MEMORY.md` (curated long-term)
- `memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md` (daily append logs)

For exact recall (IDs/error codes), supplement semantic search with explicit keyword pathing and consistent naming.

---

## 🧪 Validation plan (must pass)

### A) Compaction retention test
1. Feed 20–40 turns with key facts sprinkled in  
2. Force/trigger compaction (`/compact`)  
3. Ask for older facts  
✅ Pass if recovered with high accuracy

### B) “Remember this” durability test
1. Tell agent 5 explicit preferences  
2. Start new session or force compaction  
3. Ask preferences  
✅ Pass if all recovered

### C) Hook continuity test
1. In session A, create unique context  
2. `/new`  
3. Ask what was preserved  
✅ Pass if context snapshot available via memory files

### D) Embedding/index health test
1. Write a rare phrase in memory file  
2. `memory_search` with paraphrased query  
✅ Pass if phrase retrieved semantically

---

## 🚨 Common failure modes to watch
- Embedding key missing/expired
- Memory plugin disabled
- memoryFlush enabled but threshold too late
- Agent writes only summaries, not durable facts
- Uses memory files in dashboard UI but no retrieval in chat behavior

---

## 📌 Recommended rollout (safe)
1. Apply compaction+flush config  
2. Verify memorySearch provider/key/index  
3. Enable session-memory hook  
4. Strengthen instruction rules  
5. Run the 4 validation tests above  
6. Tune thresholds based on failures

---

## Insights to add to our report (non-Redis/Qdrant)

### 1) Memory flush before compaction is critical
**Why:** Prevents “I forgot right after one message” behavior when context compacts.  
**OpenClaw-native setting:** `agents.defaults.compaction.memoryFlush` (enable + tune threshold).  
This is likely the biggest win.

### 2) Vector/semantic memory search should be enabled and verified
The video calls this “semantic memory search”; OpenClaw docs call it vector memory search under built-in memory.  
**Key point:** It’s not enough to “turn on” — embeddings provider/API key + indexing must be healthy.

### 3) Auto-capture / explicit memory write behavior matters
The theme is: don’t rely on model implicit memory.  
You need behavior rules/prompting that force durable writes (`MEMORY.md` + daily logs) for preferences, decisions, constraints.

### 4) Session-memory hook helps with resets/new sessions
If you use `/new` flows, enabling `session-memory` preserves continuity snapshots into files.  
That closes a common “new session = memory gap” issue.

### 5) Hybrid retrieval improves exact recall
Video mentions hybrid search (keywords + semantic).  
In OpenClaw terms, this maps well to using:
- semantic `memory_search`
- targeted `memory_get`
- plus file naming/structure discipline for exact-key lookups (IDs, codes, vars).

### 6) Operational fix path should be part of rollout
Video mentions config errors and doctor repair; this is practical:
- validate config changes incrementally
- keep a rollback
- if broken, use `openclaw doctor --fix` and re-apply safely

🔬 **DEEP RESEARCH REPORT: Fixing OpenClaw Memory Reliability (without Redis/Qdrant)**

## ⚡ Executive answer
Yes — there are strong OpenClaw-native ways to fix “forgetfulness,” and the most promising path is:  
1) tune **pre-compaction memory flush**,  
2) verify **vector memory search** is actually working (provider/index),  
3) enforce **memory write + recall discipline** in agent behavior, and  
4) enable **session-memory hook** for `/new` continuity.

---

## 📊 Confidence
**High** on the architecture and fix sequence (matches OpenClaw docs + video pattern).  
**Medium** on exact values for your environment until we run validation tests.

---

## ✅ Most promising solutions (ranked)

### 1) Enable/tune compaction memory flush (highest impact)
**Why:** Most “forgot right away” failures happen around compaction boundaries.  
**What to set:**
```json5
agents: {
  defaults: {
    compaction: {
      mode: "safeguard",
      reserveTokensFloor: 20000,
      memoryFlush: {
        enabled: true,
        softThresholdTokens: 4000,
        systemPrompt: "Session nearing compaction. Store durable memories now.",
        prompt: "Write lasting notes to memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md and MEMORY.md when appropriate. Reply NO_REPLY if nothing durable."
      }
    }
  }
}
```
Tune `softThresholdTokens` upward if you still lose context before flush occurs.

---

### 2) Make vector memory search actually operational
**Why:** “Enabled but not functioning” is common (missing embedding key/provider/index state).  
**Key checks:**
- `agents.defaults.memorySearch` configured (provider + model)
- embedding API key present (OpenAI/Gemini/Voyage/Mistral)
- memory backend not disabled (`plugins.slots.memory != "none"`)
- file paths include your actual memory files

Example baseline:
```json5
agents: {
  defaults: {
    memorySearch: {
      provider: "openai", // or gemini/voyage/mistral/local
      model: "text-embedding-3-small"
    }
  }
}
```

---

### 3) Enforce durable-write behavior in agent instructions
**Why:** Storage fails when agent isn’t consistently told what is “durable.”  
Add explicit rules in AGENTS/SOUL/system behavior:

- If user says “remember this” → write immediately
- Preferences/decisions/constraints → MEMORY.md
- Daily context/work log → memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md
- No “mental note” promises without file write

This reduces silent memory drift.

---

### 4) Enable session-memory hook for `/new` continuity
**Why:** New-session transitions can look like “amnesia.”  
Enable:
```bash
openclaw hooks enable session-memory
```
This captures recent context to memory files when resetting session.

---

### 5) Improve recall discipline (before answering memory questions)
**Why:** Retrieval isn’t automatic unless behavior enforces it.  
Policy:
- Before answers about prior decisions/preferences/dates/todos:
  1) `memory_search`
  2) `memory_get` on top hits
  3) answer with confidence and mention uncertainty if weak

This avoids hallucinated recall.

---

### 6) Use cleaner memory structure + optional hybrid strategy
Keep:
- `MEMORY.md` (curated long-term)
- `memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md` (daily append logs)

For exact recall (IDs/error codes), supplement semantic search with explicit keyword pathing and consistent naming.

---

## 🧪 Validation plan (must pass)

### A) Compaction retention test
1. Feed 20–40 turns with key facts sprinkled in  
2. Force/trigger compaction (`/compact`)  
3. Ask for older facts  
✅ Pass if recovered with high accuracy

### B) “Remember this” durability test
1. Tell agent 5 explicit preferences  
2. Start new session or force compaction  
3. Ask preferences  
✅ Pass if all recovered

### C) Hook continuity test
1. In session A, create unique context  
2. `/new`  
3. Ask what was preserved  
✅ Pass if context snapshot available via memory files

### D) Embedding/index health test
1. Write a rare phrase in memory file  
2. `memory_search` with paraphrased query  
✅ Pass if phrase retrieved semantically

---

## 🚨 Common failure modes to watch
- Embedding key missing/expired
- Memory plugin disabled
- memoryFlush enabled but threshold too late
- Agent writes only summaries, not durable facts
- Uses memory files in dashboard UI but no retrieval in chat behavior

---

## 📌 Recommended rollout (safe)
1. Apply compaction+flush config  
2. Verify memorySearch provider/key/index  
3. Enable session-memory hook  
4. Strengthen instruction rules  
5. Run the 4 validation tests above  
6. Tune thresholds based on failures

Yep — I dug in. Good news: Orion isn’t actually “thinking in loops.” This looks like a **delivery/rendering glitch**, not a bad Orion run.

### What I found
- Orion’s raw session file for that exact task contains **one clean final response** (not the giant repeated blob).
- The duplication you saw (`IDoneDone...` with repeated chunks) appears to have happened **after** Orion generated the message — likely in gateway/webchat streaming/relay.
- Your stack is also slightly version-skewed:
  - Gateway app: `2026.2.19-2`
  - CLI: `2026.2.21-2`
  - Update available: `2026.2.23`
  
That mismatch can absolutely cause weird stream behavior like repeated fragments.

### Likely root cause
**Gateway/webchat stream chunk duplication** (or reconnect replay), not Orion logic.

### Recommended fix (in order)
1. **Restart gateway** (quick reset of stream state)
   - `openclaw gateway restart`
2. **Update OpenClaw** to current
   - `openclaw update`
3. Test Orion with a short prompt and confirm output is clean.

Yep — I dug in. Good news: Orion isn’t actually “thinking in loops.” This looks like a **delivery/rendering glitch**, not a bad Orion run.

### What I found
- Orion’s raw session file for that exact task contains **one clean final response** (not the giant repeated blob).
- The duplication you saw (`IDoneDone...` with repeated chunks) appears to have happened **after** Orion generated the message — likely in gateway/webchat streaming/relay.
- Your stack is also slightly version-skewed:
  - Gateway app: `2026.2.19-2`
  - CLI: `2026.2.21-2`
  - Update available: `2026.2.23`
  
That mismatch can absolutely cause weird stream behavior like repeated fragments.

### Likely root cause
**Gateway/webchat stream chunk duplication** (or reconnect replay), not Orion logic.

### Recommended fix (in order)
1. **Restart gateway** (quick reset of stream state)
   - `openclaw gateway restart`
2. **Update OpenClaw** to current
   - `openclaw update`
3. Test Orion with a short prompt and confirm output is clean.

If you want, I can run the restart/update sequence now and then re-check Orion behavior right after.
ok, please do
On it — I’ll restart the gateway, run the update, then verify Orion with a quick sanity check.

- **SMM daily social posting (9:00 ET) is blocked** across X/IG/FB/LinkedIn/Threads because Chrome relay/browser control wasn’t connected, so nothing published.
- **Dev session** also shows a recent `Not Found` error on last run.

If you want, I’ll triage these in order:  
1) clear the browser relay blocker first (so posts can run),  
2) then validate Dev session health.
